MotorCommands.Description: Disables the MOSFETS (note that MOSFETs are disabled after initial power on).
Enables the MOSFETS.
Move immediately to the given position using the currently set speed (the speed is set by a separate command)

Input.Description: The displacement to travel. Can be positive or negative.
The time over which to do the move.

MotorCommands.Description: Sets maximum velocity (this is not used at this time)

Input.Description: Maximum velocity.

MotorCommands.Description: Move to this new given position in the amount of time specified. Acceleration and deceleration will be applied to make the move smooth.

Input.Description: New absolute position value.
Time allowed for executing the move.

MotorCommands.Description: Sets max acceleration

Input.Description: The maximum acceleration.

MotorCommands.Description: Starts a calibration, which will determine the average values of the hall sensors and will determine if they are working correctly
Start sending hall sensor data (work in progress; don't send this command)

Input.Description: Indicates the type of data to capture. Currently 1 to 3 are valid.
Number of points to read back from the device
Channels to capture bitmask. The first three bits are valid, which will turn on (0) or turn off (0) that hall sensor channel
Aquire a sample every this number of time steps. Time steps happen at the update frequency, which can be read with the Get product specs command
Number of samples to sum together to make one point to transmit back
Division factor to apply to the sum of the samples to scale it down before transmitting it so that it fits into the returned data type, which is a 16-bit number per each hall sensor

Output.Description: The data of the hall sensors after suming and averaging

MotorCommands.Description: Resets the absolute time to zero (call this first before issuing any movement commands)
Gets the current absolute time

Output.Description: The current absolute time

MotorCommands.Description: Sends the master time to the motor so that it can sync its own clock (do this 10 times per second).

Input.Description: : The motor absolute time that the motor should sync to (in microseconds).

Output.Description: The error in the motor's time compared to the master time.
The contents of the RCC-ICSCR register (holds the HSICAL and HSITRIM settings).

MotorCommands.Description: Get the number of items currently in the movement queue (if this gets too large, don't queue any more movement commands)

Output.Description: The number of items in the movement queue. This command will return between 0 and 32. If less than 32, you can add more items to the queue to continue the movements in order without stopping.

MotorCommands.Description: Emergency stop (stop all movement, disable MOSFETS, clear the queue)
Make the current position the position zero (origin)
Homing (or in other words, move until a crash and then stop immediately)

Input.Description: The maximum distance to move (if a crash does not occur). This can be positive or negative. the sign determines the direction of movement.
The maximum time to allow for homing. Make sure to give enough time for the motor to cover the maximum distance or the motor may move too fast or throw a fatal error.

MotorCommands.Description: Get the position as measured by the hall sensors (this should be the actual position of the motor and if everything is ok then it will be about the same as the desired position)

Output.Description: The current position as determined by the hall sensors

MotorCommands.Description: Gets the status of the motor

Output.Description: A series of flags which are 1 bit each
BitDescriptions: Bit 0: In the bootloader (if this flag is set then the other flags below will all be 0)
Bit 2: Motor is in closed loop mode
Bit 3: Motor is currently executing the calibration command
Bit 4: Motor is currently executing a homing command
Bit 5: Motor is currently executing the procedure to go to closed loop mode
Bit 6: Motor is currently busy doing a time consuming task and is not ready to take another command

Output.Description: The fatal error code. If 0 then there is no fatal error. Once a fatal error happens, the motor becomes disabled and cannot do much anymore until reset. You can press the reset button on the motor or you can execute the System reset command to get out of the fatal error state.

MotorCommands.Description: Go to closed loop position control mode
Get the update frequency (reciprocal of the time step)

Output.Description: Update frequency in Hz. This is how often the motor executes all calculations for hall sensor position, movement, PID loop, safety, etc.
Counts per rotation. When commanding the motor or when reading back position, this is the number of counts per one shaft rotation.

MotorCommands.Description: Rotates the motor with the specified acceleration

Input.Description: The acceleration (the unit is microsteps per time step per time step * 2^24).

The number of time steps to apply this acceleration. Use command 18 to get the frequency of the time steps. After this many time steps, the acceleration will go to zero and velocity will be maintained.

MotorCommands.Description: Detect all of the devices that are connected on the RS485 interface. Devices will identify themselves at a random time within one second. Chance of collision is possible but unlikely. You can repeat this if you suspect a collision (like if you have devices connected but they were not discovered within one to two seconds).

Output.Description: A unique ID (unique among all devices manufactured). The response is sent after a random delay of between 0 and 1 seconds.
The alias of the device that has this unique ID.

MotorCommands.Description: Sets device alias

Input.Description: The alias (which is a one byte ID) ranging from 0 to 251. It cannot be 252 to 254 because those are reserved. You can set it to 255, which will remove the alias.

MotorCommands.Description: Get product information

Output.Description: The product code / model number (when doing a firmware upgrade, this must match between the firmware file and the target device).
A firmware compatibility code (when doing a firmware upgrade, this must match between the firmware file and the target device).
The hardware version stored as 3 bytes. The first byte is the patch version, followed by the minor and major versions.
The serial number.
The unique ID for the product.
Not currently used.

MotorCommands.Description: This command will upgrade the flash memory of the servo motor. Before issuing a firmware upgrade command, you must do some calculations as shown in the examples.

Input.Description: The data to upgrade one page of flash memory. Contents includes the product model code (8 bytes), firmware compatibility code (1 byte), page number (1 byte), and the page data itself (2048 bytes).

MotorCommands.Description: Get the product description.

Output.Description: : This is a brief description of the product.

MotorCommands.Description: Get the firmware version or the bootloader version depending on what mode we are in. This command also returns the status bits, where the least significan bit teels us if we are currently in the bootloader (=1) or the main firmware (=0)

Output.Description: The firmware version stored as 4 bytes. The first byte is the development number, then patch version, followed by the minor and major versions.
: A flag that tells us if we are in the bootloader (=1) or in the regular firmware (=0)

MotorCommands.Description: Rotates the motor with the specified velocity.

Input.Description: The velocity (the unit is microsteps per time step * 2^20).
The time to maintain this velocity.

MotorCommands.Description: System reset / go to the bootloader. The motor will reset immediately and will enter the bootloader. If there is no command sent within a short time, the motor will exit the bootloader and run the application from the beginning.
Set the maximum motor current and maximum regeneration current. The values are stored in non-volatile memory and survive a reset.

Input.Description: The motor current. The units are some arbitrary units and not amps. A value of 150 or 200 is suitable.
The motor regeneration current (while it is braking). This parameter is currently not used for anything.

MotorCommands.Description: The multimove command allows you to compose multiple moves one after another. Please note that when the queue becomes empty after all the moves are executed and the motor is not at a standstill then a fatal error will be triggered.

Input.Description: Specify how many moves are being communicated in this one shot.
Each bit specifies if the move is a (bit = 0) MOVE_WITH_ACCELERATION_COMMAND or a (bit = 1) MOVE_WITH_VELOCITY_COMMAND.

A 2D list in Python format (list of lists). Each item in the list is of type [i32, u32] representing a series of move commands. Each move command specifies the acceleration to move at or the velocity to instantly change to (according to the bits above) and the number of time steps over which this command is to be executed. For example: '[[100, 30000], [-200, 60000]]'. There is a limit of 32 move commands that can be listed in this one multi-move command. Each of the moves takes up one queue spot, so make sure there is enough space in the queue to store all of the commands.

MotorCommands.Description: Set safety limits (to prevent motion from exceeding set bounds)

Input.Description: : The lower limit in microsteps.
The upper limit in microsteps.

MotorCommands.Description: Send a payload containing any data and the device will respond with the same data back

Input.Description: Any binary data payload to send to the device.

Output.Description: The same data that was sent to the device will be returned if all went well.

MotorCommands.Description: Turn on or off the gathering of statistics for the hall sensors and reset the statistics

Input.Description: 0 = turn off statistics gathering, 1 = reset statistics and turn on gathering.

MotorCommands.Description: Read back the statistics gathered from the hall sensors. Useful for checking the hall sensor health and noise in the system.

Output.Description: The maximum value of hall sensor 1 encoutered since the last statistics reset.
The maximum value of hall sensor 2 encoutered since the last statistics reset.
The maximum value of hall sensor 3 encoutered since the last statistics reset.
The minimum value of hall sensor 1 encoutered since the last statistics reset.
The minimum value of hall sensor 2 encoutered since the last statistics reset.
The minimum value of hall sensor 3 encoutered since the last statistics reset.
The sum of hall sensor 1 values collected since the last statistics reset.
The sum of hall sensor 2 values collected since the last statistics reset.
The sum of hall sensor 3 values collected since the last statistics reset.
The number of times the hall sensors were measured since the last statistics reset.

MotorCommands.Description: Get the current desired position (which may differ a bit from the actual position as measured by the hall sensors)

Output.Description: The current desired position

MotorCommands.Description: Read whatever is in the multipurpose buffer (the buffer is used for data generated during calibration, going to closed loop mode, and when capturing hall sensor data)

Output.Description: The data in the buffer (the format and length of the data depends on what was put in the buffer)

MotorCommands.Description: Set or trigger a certain test mode. This is a bit undocumented at the moment. Don't use this unless you are a developer working on test cases.

Input.Description: The test mode to use or trigger

MotorCommands.Description: Get the desired motor position, hall sensor position, and external encoder position all in one shot

Output.Description: The commanded position (which may differ from actual)
The hall sensor position (or you could say the actual measured position)
The external encoder position. This needs special hardware attached to the motor to work

MotorCommands.Description: Get the measured voltage of the power supply.

Output.Description: The voltage. Divide this number by 10 to get the actual voltage in volts.

MotorCommands.Description: Get the minimum and maximum error value ovserved in the PID control loop since the last read.

Output.Description: The minimum PID error value.
The maximum PID error value.

MotorCommands.Description: Cause the motor to start to vary the voltage quickly and therefore to vibrate (or stop).

Input.Description: Vibration level (0 = turn off, 1 = turn on).

MotorCommands.Description: Identify your motor by sending this command. The motor's green LED will flash rapidly for 3 seconds.
Get the measured temperature of the motor.

Output.Description: The temperature in degrees celcius. The accuracy is about +/- 3 degrees celcius and is measured at the motor driver PCB.

MotorCommands.Description: Set PID constants for the control loop that will try to maintain the motion trajectory.

Input.Description: The proportional term constant (P)
The integral term constant (I)
The differential term constant (D)

MotorCommands.Description: Set the amount of microsteps that the actual motor position (as measured by the hall sensors) is allowed to deviate from the desired position. Throw a fatal error if this is exceeded.

Input.Description: The new maximum allowable position deviation setting

MotorCommands.Description: Get debug values including motor control parameters, profiler times, hall sensor data, and other diagnostic information.

Output.Description: Maximum acceleration setting
Maximum velocity setting
Current velocity
Measured velocity
: Number of time steps left in the current move
Debug value 1
Debug value 2
Debug value 3
Debug value 4
All motor control calculations profiler time
All motor control calculations profiler maximum time
Get sensor position profiler time
Get sensor position profiler maximum time
Compute velocity profiler time
Compute velocity profiler maximum time
Motor movement calculations profiler time
Motor movement calculations profiler maximum time
Motor phase calculations profiler time
Motor phase calculations profiler maximum time
Motor control loop period profiler time
Motor control loop period profiler maximum time
Hall sensor 1 voltage
Hall sensor 2 voltage
Hall sensor 3 voltage
Commutation position offset
Motor phases reversed flag
Maximum hall position delta
Minimum hall position delta
Average hall position delta
Motor PWM voltage

MotorCommands.Description: Enable or disable CRC32 checking for commands

Input.Description: Control value (1 to enable, 0 to disable CRC32 checking)

MotorCommands.Description: Get and optionally reset the CRC32 error counter

Input.Description: Reset flag (1 to reset the counter after reading, 0 to just read)

Output.Description: Number of CRC32 errors detected
Number of packet decode errors detected

Errors.long_desc: No error condition
The system detected that time appeared to move backwards, which indicates a problem with the microsecond clock
Failed to unlock the flash memory for writing
solutions: Verify flash unlock sequence in code

Errors.long_desc: Failed to write data to flash memory
Data size exceeds buffer or memory limits
Command buffer overflow detected
causes: Too many commands sent too quickly

Errors.long_desc: Individual command exceeds maximum allowed length
An operation that requires open loop control mode was attempted while the motor was in a different control mode
causes: Attempting calibration while not in open loop mode
solutions: Switch to open loop mode before calibration
Reset motor control mode to open loop
Check mode transition logic in code

Errors.long_desc: An operation that requires an empty movement queue was attempted while the queue still had pending movements
causes: Attempting mode change with active movements
solutions: Wait for all movements to complete

Errors.long_desc: Hall sensor readings are invalid or out of expected range
Calibration data buffer overflow during motor calibration
Insufficient number of peaks detected during hall sensor calibration
Error in four-step vibration sequence during motor testing
An operation that requires closed loop control mode was attempted while in a different mode
causes: Attempting position control in wrong mode
solutions: Switch to closed loop mode first

Errors.long_desc: Motor supply voltage exceeds maximum allowed limit
The requested acceleration exceeds the maximum allowed acceleration limit
The requested velocity exceeds the maximum allowed velocity limit
Movement queue is full and cannot accept more commands
Movement queue unexpectedly empty during operation
An operation was attempted while the motor was busy with another operation like calibration or homing
solutions: Wait for current operation to complete

Errors.long_desc: The protocol used to communication over RS485 supports a total packet size that cannot be larger than 65535 bytes. The maximum payload size is just a bit less than this (about 65530 bytes). We have requested to capture hall sensor data that is larger than this maximum payload size.
causes: We called the Capture hall sensor data command and gave it innapropriate parameters. The two relevant parameters are: (1) Number of points to read back from the device and (2) Channels to capture bitmask. The number of bits set in this second parameter multipled by two bytes per value multiplied by this first parameter determines the payload size.
solutions: Decrease the number of points to read back or disable reading back some of the channels. For instance, setting a bistmask to 1 will read back just one channel and that will cost two bytes per point.

Errors.long_desc: The data could not be transmitted back over RS485 fast enough to keep up with the rate of capturing the data
causes: We called the Capture hall sensor data command and gave it innapropriate parameters
solutions: You can do one of the following: (1) Disable some of the channels that you wish to capture by setting bits in the bitmask parameter to 0, or (2) You can capture less often by increasing the time steps per capture parameter, or (3) average more sameples together by increasing the number of samples to sum parameter

Errors.long_desc: The motor current sensor readings are outside expected baseline range
Configured maximum PWM voltage exceeds hardware limits
Multi-move sequence exceeds maximum allowed number of moves
The motor position has exceeded the configured safety limits

Errors.short_desc: turn point out of safety zone
Errors.long_desc: Calculated movement turn point exceeds safety zone limits

Errors.short_desc: predicted position out of safety zone
Errors.long_desc: Movement trajectory would exceed safety zone limits
Movement would result in velocity exceeding limits
Debug error used for development testing
The motor control loop calculations exceeded the maximum allowed time
Array or buffer index exceeds valid range

Errors.short_desc: can't pulse when intervals are active
Errors.long_desc: Pulse command attempted while interval timing active
Attempted to set invalid motor run mode
Configuration parameter exceeds valid range
Operation requires MOSFETs to be disabled first
Communication framing error detected
Communication buffer overrun detected
Communication noise detected
Failed to transition from open loop to closed loop control mode
solutions: Ensure stable motor position before transition

Errors.long_desc: Motor or controller temperature too high
Operation not allowed while test mode is active
Mismatch between expected and actual position after movement
Motor current exceeds maximum allowed limit
The calculated PWM duty cycle exceeds the maximum allowed value
The difference between commanded position and actual position exceeds allowed limits
Requested movement distance exceeds system limits
The change in hall sensor position between updates is larger than expected
The received first byte does not have the least significant bit set to 1
causes: Incorrect first byte encoding of the communication packet
Sender not compliant with protocol requirements
solutions: Ensure all first bytes have LSB set to 1
Verify baud rates are the same on both ends
Update sender software to comply with protocol

Errors.long_desc: Some invalid parameters were given when invoking the Capture hall sensor data command
causes: A capture type other than 1, 2, or 3 was given
The number of points to be captures was given as 0, which implies that you do not want any data
The number of time steps per sample was given as 0, which implies an infinite sampling rate
The number of samples to sum together was given as 0, which implies that you do not want any data
The division factor was given as 0, which implies that you want to divide by 0, which implies that you do not remember high school math
The bitmask that specifies the channels you want to capture was not valid. You either chose no channels or you chose channels that don't exits.
solutions: Give 1, 2, or 3 as the capture type
Give a value that is 1 or higher
Give a value that is 1 or higher
Give a value that is 1 or higher
Give a value that is 1 or higher
Normally, 7 specifies that all three channels should be captured. If you want to capture just one channel, choose either 1 (first channel only), 2 (second channel only), or 4 (third channel only).

Errors.long_desc: You tried to set the device to one of the reserved aliases such as 254, 253, or 252
causes: You tried to set the device to one of the reserved aliases such as 254, 253, or 252, which is not allowed. These aliases have special purposes.
solutions: When using the Set device alias command, make sure to use an allowed alias, which is 0 to 251. You can also set the alias to 255, which is the broadcast alias, which is similar like having no alias set.

Errors.long_desc: The payload sent with the command does not match the expected size of the input parameters
causes: You have sent a command that does not have the expected parameters or sizes of parameters
Data was corrupted somehow during transmission over RS485 and you do not have CRC32 enabled to ensure integrity
You have not used the communication protocol correctly. For instance, you did not encode the size of the packet correctly.
solutions: Make sure to send the correct parameters with all the correct size, Look at motor_commands.json for the details about every command and its parameters
Ensure good connections and grounding on the communication line and use CRC32 to ensure packet integrity
Check the documentation about the protocol and make sure that the packet you are sending is correctly formatted and that the packet size is right

Errors.long_desc: You are sending a firmware packet and the specified firmware page to be written is not valid and out of range
causes: You have sent a firmware upgrade packet and the specified firmware page is not one that can be written. Maybe the firmware size that you are trying to write is too big?
solutions: Make sure to send the correct firmware page numbers and ensure the firmware is not too big. You can look at the FIRST_FIRMWARE_PAGE_NUMBER and LAST_FIRMWARE_PAGE_NUMBER settings in settings.h
Study the protocol and make sure that everything is encoded right

Errors.long_desc: You tried to trigger a certain test mode but it is not a valid one
causes: You are a user and doing something you should not and generally don't understand what you are getting yourself into
You are a developer and you did not study the source code enough yet to use the test modes successfully
solutions: Don't call the Test mode command
Keep studying the source code until you know how this works
